title.narrative: Drought response in Somalia (part of SHO-action)

description.narrative: Providing access to water to drought struck families

Somalia is in the grip of an intense drought, induced by up to four consecutive seasons of poor rainfall. Since mid-2015, drought conditions have been expanding with impact worsening over time. The latest food security and nutrition analysis from the FAO reveals that the number of people in need of humanitarian aid increased to 6,2 million between February and June 2017. That is more than half of the population. The situation for children is especially grave. In addition, preliminary forecasts indicate that below to near average rainfall is expected to prevail across most parts of Somalia during the forthcoming 2017 Gu season (April – June). As a result, further deterioration in food security is possible, setting the stage for a possible famine this year, if humanitarian assistance does not reach the beneficiaries in time. Urgent action to ramp up assistance provision and ensure adequate humanitarian access is needed to address rising levels of food insecurity and mitigate the potential for large-scale loss of life. ACT Somalia Forum members have carried out needs assessments in partnership with local district leaders, community elders and government entities. Gender, age and sex were also considered during data collection to determine women’s involvement in decision making process and resource control and management. As a result, the following priority needs have been identified: access to food for vulnerable pastoralist households; water and sanitation facilities particularly for women and girls; protection of productive assets for vulnerable pastoralist households; protection for children; psychosocial support for people living with specific needs. In Galgudug, where DKH will intervene, all surface water sources are dry; subsurface water is the only water available by now, accessible through boreholes and few and wide-spread wells. As part of the ACT Somalia Forum and ACT Appeal SOM171, DKH plans to respond through WASH activities, including rehabilitation of boreholes, water vouchers, cash-for-work and unconditional cash transfers. The contribution from Kerk in Actie & ICCO is coming from the funds raised through the national campaign of SHO for ‘Help victims of hunger’

The food security and malnutrition situation in Somalia is alarming due to drought exacerbated by El Nino, with over 6 million people in need. In Galgudug region, ICCO & Kerk in Actie is responding through the ACT Alliance by providing activities aimed at increasing access to water including: rehabilitation of boreholes, water vouchers, cash-for-work and unconditional cash transfers.
